Sadly, their arrival here wasn’t enough to sustain them.

title: https://arxiv.org/pdf/2303.12712.pdf

last_post.content:
I'm less sanguine about LLMs than I was in December when I said they're essentially "asking a supercomputer to get really good at mansplaining."

I really encourage folks to check out this paper on some of GPT4's capabilities.
https://arxiv.org/pdf/2303.12712.pdf

Some of this is undoubtedly overstated. And none of this disputes the very real concerns about bias, misuse, and disinformation.

But look at some of these examples (pics attached). It's hard to reconcile with "word prediction on steroids."

title: Judge Decides Against Internet Archive

last_post.content:
The judgment against the Internet Archive is (unsurprisingly) harsh.
“At bottom, IA’s fair use defense rests on the notion that lawfully acquiring a copyrighted print book entitles the recipient to make an unauthorized copy and distribute it in place of the print book, so long as it does not simultaneously lend the print book. But no case or legal principle supports that notion. Every authority points the other direction.” https://file770.com/judge-decides-against-internet-archive/

title: https://thi.ng/umbrella

last_post.content:
#TypeScript 5.0 has a new compiler flag "verbatimModuleSyntax" which supersedes the now deprecated "importsNotUsedAsValues" and changes how type-only imports are being treated[1]. TypeScript catches most (not all!) of these occurrences as bugs, and after reviewing imports all 4000(!)+ resulting JavaScript files over the weekend (and finding & fixing another dozen or so cases), I just pushed new releases of all 179 #ThingUmbrella packages[2], now compatible with TS5.0! 🎉

One other (somewhat related) still outstanding issue to address soon is the new TC39-compatible decorator handling/behavior... I already tried updating these semi-successfully, but then deferred the work again when I realized that I'll first have to do a lot more reading & experimenting with this new setup (esp. related to mixins). The changes are quite major... Anyhow, steady progress, small steps, more often...

Happy Coding! :)

[1] https://devblogs.microsoft.com/typescript/announcing-typescript-5-0/#breaking-changes-and-deprecations

[2] https://thi.ng/umbrella

title: Communication networks do not predict success in attempts at peer production

last_post.content:
🚨 New paper!

Blog post + thread coming sometime this week, but @aaronshaw, @mako, and I just had our paper published on the role of networks in early-stage wiki communities.

https://academic.oup.com/jcmc/article/28/3/zmad002/7084918

The TL;DR is that structure doesn't predict productivity or longevity of communities very well at all!

We talk about some potential explanations, but I still think it's surprising!

title: Mastodon Migration (@mastodonmigration@mastodon.online)

last_post.content:
Mastodon new user update.

New users, which had been hovering in the low 100's per hour in February and early March, have risen steadily and are now consistently above 1500 per hour. This seems to not correlate to any specific event, but rather may be the the result of a more sustained Network Effect.

For more on Network Effects... >>> https://mastodon.online/@mastodonmigration/109892843992575733

title: The Unraveling of the U.S. News College Rankings

last_post.content:
Each year, #USNews & World Reports rank colleges and universities, as follows: they try a bunch of different ranking algorithms, see which generates the results they like, and then choose which to deploy.

I mean we all knew that their rankings were absolute crap, but the fact that anyone would out and admit this in public—while not under oath–is truly remarkable.

https://www.wsj.com/articles/u-s-news-college-rankings-yale-law-fe24f0b2

ht @briannosek

title: https://www.dabeaz.com/compiler.html

last_post.content:
I think you should join me in writing a compiler from scratch. May 1-5. https://www.dabeaz.com/compiler.html

A compilers course changed the whole trajectory of my graduate studies.

It impacts others in different ways. I once had a former student come back tell me how skills learned while writing a compiler helped save a major healthcare website.

A lot of things have to come together in a compiler and a lot of the takeaways are useful elsewhere.

title: To Hold Tech Accountable, Look to Public Health

last_post.content:
New in WIRED: A public health model of tech governance would detect & remediate tech harms while also supporting societal well-being & preventing future crises.

Yet public health, like the tech industry, has systematically failed marginalized communities in ways that are not accidents. How can tech governance do better from the start?

https://www.wired.com/story/tech-governance-public-health/amp

title: Government funds mandatory air purifiers at schools - The Korea Herald

last_post.content:
South Korean Governmen funds mandatory air purifiers at schools

The government passed a revised school health act to improve quality of air and safety at preschools and primary and secondary schools.

The law requires installation of air-cleaning and air quality sensors in classrooms and allows state funds to cover costs. School councils and parents are also permitted to attend classroom air quality monitoring sessions, which will be conducted each semester.

@whn #covid
https://www.koreaherald.com/view.php?ud=20190327000802

title: Security Risks of Government Hacking

last_post.content: The Biden EO obviously has plenty of holes in it, but it's still a big deal. Condemning other govs' use of these tools rings hollow unless we commit to staying out of that market ourselves, as I wrote in 2018: https://cyberlaw.stanford.edu/publications/security-risks-government-hacking
